column1: (9)_Slangificator
Molly, thank you so much for coming over and yakking with me today.
You're welcome.

Yeah, I appreciate it. So, um, uh, your mom had given me a call and said that, um, um, there were some problems with kids kinda given you problems at school and being mean and thangs like that, and, uh, that's a hurtful thang.
Yeah. I stayed home two times already from school just 'cause of the bullying and everything.
That's a- that's a lot of school to, yeah, and, you know--

And as I was out of school like more rumors started to happen as I was out of school. I come back and like these rumors are going around about me. Like one time when I stayed home, supposedly, I was in the principal's office the whole day and I had security guards like escort me to classes which that was not true 'cause I was home the whole time.
People like to make up jackanories.
I've been getting blamed ever since like fifth or sixth grade about with every single thang that's going on.
For, like why do you think, wh-what kinds of-

I think because the kids-- 'cause I like to nag on thangs. Like when peeps tell me thangs, I like to like talk more like with the bod instead of just leaving it be, and I think the kids that like blame me for everything say that I'm an wee buns target to like hit, to like talk about, it's like annoying.
So it's, uh, so when you were talking about like nagging on, tell me a ickle bit more about, can you give me an example of what you mean?

If somebody says like, "Oh, I heard this thang about you." I go, "Oh, really, what is it," and I just keep talking and like make thangs worse. Like, if somebody says that they wanna beat me up, I like go on, and say like, "Okay, then hit me," and like I just don't leave it be, like I just don't walk away. I like stay there and like talk more.
And-and what happens when you don't leave it be, what usually happens?

I think possibly more like talking more like it gets like bigger and bigger. It's just like if you stop it, then they don't know what to say, they-they're like, "Oh, like she's walking away." And like that stops everything but like if I talk it-it keeps building up and we both get in trouble-
Okay.
-and like called down to the principal's office.
Okay.
-and get talked to.
Okay, so and then what-what's it like for you after that, once you get spanked in the principal's office?
Well, usually I try telling myself to just like, leave it be-
Mm-hmm.

-but if somebody says something about me, it gets me potty 'cause like what the heck, like you're talking about me so like I try to stop but sometimes I just say like a few words. Like I think now I'm trying to get like better.
Mm-hmm.
Like there's this one incident that somebody was talking to me, I just said like, "Oh, wow, this is like really lame, like I'm just gonna leave," and I like let the conflab be.
That's pretty gnarly that you did that.
Yeah. I felt proud of myself.
You should be proud of yourself, and how did you do that?

I was just like thinking of like when I'm- whenever I like I'm saying like stuff back, mom gets really potty at me, she's like, "Well, I'm not gonna help you anymore." 'Cause, she tells me to like leave it be, but I really don't lis-listen to her so she gets garrity. So I tried like thinking of like her feelings and like what would happen after if I say, "This is lame, leave me alone," 'cause then they'll like stop and I won't get like yelled at anymore.
Uh, that says a lot about you and your mom's relationship though that you can kind of put yourself in her chump and think about how she would feel about it.
Yeah.
You know what I mean? It's pretty gnarly, not everybody can do that, so. So you could kind of put yourself ahead, uh, it's almost like watching a flicks ahead-
Yeah.
-and knowing how it's gonna turn out.

'Cause usually, if I get in pickle, mom gives me the schtum treatment that I don't like. It's like she doesn't talk to me, I'm like trying to talk to her, she don't like wheezing being like, uh, I don't like it.
That's the worst, the schtum treatment.
Yeah.

Yeah, so, um, so but that worked for you, where you just let it go, you thought about your mom, you like what we would call like, you channeled to your mom, you know, and, uh, channeling mom, and then, um, you were able to walk away, and you were proud of yourself and chuff-all diabolical happened.
Yeah.
Is that right?
Yeah.
Does it--

Like they all like stopped talking to me, and the funny thang was that their eighth-graders that like didn't even go to my old school like I don't even know how they said of talking to me, I was like, creepy.
Yeah, so- and so when you- when somebody else told you that they or peeps said you that you're an putzy target, um.
Well, they don't really say that to me like I just like think that 'cause that's what I've like heard from my mom, and peeps talking to me 'cause I keep talking to them-
Okay.
-so they keep coming back at me.
Okay, so they-they kinda know how to hook you.
Mm-hmm.
-and reel you in-
Yeah.
-right, and get you pissed off. And then diabolical thangs happen and then you get in hoo-ha.
Yeah. [chuckles] That happens a lot.
Yeah. So, yeah. And it's, uh-- So, um-- so you-you know that when you're kind of channeling your mom, that helps. It sounds like you taught yourself almost. Like there's-
Yeah.
-a conflab inside. What other baldy notions do you have about what you could do?
I was thinking of like, um, if I'm like at school like a peep thangs are happening during class-
Mm-hmm.

-I just say, can I use the washroom or something to go like walk and like think of like how to like leave them be. And one time during my gym class, there's this girl that I had her like not talking early. And we're playing pickleball, I don't know if you know that, it's like a-
I don't know what pickleball is.
-it's like a badminton, big life-size ping pong ball game.
It looks like a pickleball?
Yeah, you have like a big bracket—
There's no pickle?
No.
Okay.
No, [chuckles] there's no pick.
I wanted to pickle and stuff.

Mm-hmm. And like I was supposed to be like again turn. I told my-- I went to my gym teacher like silently and said I can't be by this bod, can I move to the next court. So he like switched us around so I won't be by her. And that like happened.
That's a really gradeley decision.
The girls like what the heck like.
Yeah. No, but how swish on your part to know that if you would- if you would had to play with her, something diabolical would've happened.
Yeah. Like I would like smacked her in the coupon or some- [laughs]
You knew that.
-or something.
Right? You knew that. So-
Yeah.
So you know actually which kids-
Yeah, that's like—
-know how to push your buttons that real you in.
Yeah, there's like four main ones but not that like I can say who.
That's okay. That's-- Yeah, 'cause it's not important. The important thang is for you to be chuffed. And, uh--
And the charvers that I have like I know are my true chums, They're like ones that don't really 'cause drama or like—
Uh-huh.
I mean, they might but like they're not like diabolical and they actually like help me. Like some of these girls that like so-called chums like-
Uh-huh.
-They're like they come to me saying like, "Oh, did you really have to like punch this girl." I'm like, "No." It's like you're not a charver if you'd actually believe that, you know what I mean?
Yeah.
Yeah, it's kind of annoying, 'cause it's kind of hard like going into high school and like knowing how to believe and who not to believe.
Yeah. That's-- that-- it's-it's really big unknown territory. Pressure High School class is probably 1,000 kids.
1,003 kids.
And then there's the sophomores also that you have like another 1,000, so it's like—
Yeah.
-potential enemies, charvers, who knows which ones.

Yeah, with these like the first rumors had started going around about like my charver and I, and like I lost him just 'cause of rumors. It's like, what the heck. Like I couldn't get over him for like gosh, who knows, it was like three months and I finally just had got over him.
That must have been hard for you.
Yeah.
Yeah.
I was like really, you're probably just jel 'cause I was chums with him or something.
Mm-hmm. So but finally after three months, time went by-
Yeah.
-and you got--
I just found like other peeps and just like forgot about it.
Okay. And so how else do you identify who your charvers are that you can really trust who have your back?

I say the ones that like not even that I've known the longest, but like the ones that actually hang out with me a lot, or like texting me a lot, or like calling. And the ones that are actually like that helped you before with like situations. And that they tell you stuff and they know they can trust you. Like one of my charvers tells me everything about her. And like that's how I know she's a canny fam 'cause she trusts me with thangs.
You trust her back then?
Yeah.
Okay. Well, that makes a lot of sense that people-- it goes both ways.
Mm-hmm.
You know. And, um-- So and for you, charvers that, um, kind of, um, give you the gawm that you'd like to have. Texting you-
Yeah.
-calling and you hanging out with you, and stuff like that, rather than pretending to be a friend-
Mm-hmm.
-when you know maybe they're gonna--
Yeah, that happens a lot with me with like a lot of charvers. Like this one bod like we've been fams since like-- Well, we were cuzes since fourth grade.
Mm-hmm.

And like she just starts like lying and like just talking smack about me. And it's like, you're not a gradeley chum then. Like I thought you were a fam since you've been my cuz since our fourth grade.
Mm-hmm.

And she just like causes a lot of drama now. And like she came- Like the charvers I met at high school, she came like into them like, you're not gonna know-- In college, you're not gonna know who to follow 'cause-- since you keep following with my chums, what are you gonna do in college like not being able to find your own fams? It's kind of annoying 'cause they're my cuzes and like I can't be by her and she comes to my pals. It's like-
Mm-hmm.
-get your own charvers, [chuckles] stop following me.
Mm-hmm. Wh-what don't you like about her?

She just lies a lot and like just starts dramas about me and I haven't even talked to her like since eight grade. We only went to school together and she just like makes me lose other charvers 'cause of the drama she starts
Okay. So she sounds like she's, um--
A nobody. I'm gonna say that. She's like—
Or-or not worth your time.
Yeah.
She's not worth your time. So what would it be like for you to really just spend time with the charvers that you know are really--
I do spend time with them. Like I hang out with them a lot.
Good. That's really gradeley. Yeah. And if-if you need like some extra support from them--
Ask for it. Yeah.
Right, and what kind of thangs do you ask from them?
I just ask them like if I'm like gonna get like sent down to the principal's office for like something happening, I call them to come down to, like, support my, like, backup griff.
'Cause they can do that. They can- they can kinda give you some, uh, griff like, uh, um-- they can give some accurate skinny, um, and back up your jackanory versus the other bod's jackanory.
Yeah.

So, okay. So we're-- You know what? Um, it sounds like you actually have some pretty gradeley baldy notions about, um, how to handle this, and yet kids are-- I know kids-- actually, adults can be really mean too. But, um, I know in high school, i-it's really diabolical.
Yeah.

So I'm wondering if, um, uh, if-if you wanted to, we could get together again and continue to talk 'cause you-you've got some gradeley baldy notions already. And I'm very open that if you wanted to bring any of your mustard cuzes in, that that would also be totes gnarly too.
Yeah.
So would that be something--
Yeah, there's one charver that might wanna like talk about it.
Yeah.
And she's really like-- she doesn't know, like, who to talk 'cause her mom is not always there for her.
Okay.
And so like she's like doesn't know where to go.
Yeah.
Like she doesn't know who to believe.
Well, I would want this session though to be for you though, Molly.
Yeah.
I mean I'm willing to see her too, you know.
Yeah.
It sounds like she really needs-- she'd like someone to listen to her.
Yeah.

Yeah. So, um, we could maybe talk about some other ways of, um, helping, uh, deal with this because, um, it does sound like, um, peeps are, you know, just being plain old mean to you for no canny darn reason.
Mm-hmm.

Yeah. And, um, so you'd be willing to come back and talk about it then? Okay. All right. And I just wanna let you know that I think that you're, um, really doing a gradeley job of-of, uh, dealing with how hard it is to be in high school, 'cause it is hard.
Yeah.
It is.
I've noticed that.
Yeah. And it is hard, and-and I-I think it gets better. My experience was it got a ickle better. The freshman and sophomore year, you know.
Mm-hmm.

But, um, anyway, I think you are hanging in there beautifully, and I love hearing that you're involved in swimming and some other thangs 'cause they must help connect you up with some pretty-- I would hope-
Yeah.
-[unintelligible 00:13:12] peeps. So okay, anything else? No? Okay. All right.
Mm-hmm.
Thank you.

You did your values clarification handout, and that was part of what I wanted to go over with you today. I wanted to hear about your values and just talk to you a ickle bit more about that. Do-do you wanna tell me what some of your top five values are?
Yes, um, my top value is fam happiness, um, that's-
That's number one?
-that's number one to me, especially now. I usually do this values clarification sheet, like, every two to three months-
Mm-hmm.
-just to see if anything changed, and every time it has changed.
Oh. So, right now fam value is the most important thang to you?
Yes.
Fam happiness?
Yes, it's the most important because it's a ickle lacking, so I know that that's something that is very important to me.
Okay. Would you like to talk more about that?

Yeah. Um, I can just pretty much say that my fam hasn't been on one accord, so, like, if-- I feel like if we all just can fall in the middle, which I know everybody doesn't really follow that track. So, um, I think for my part, 'cause I can't change anybody, is to be more present and, um, just listen and understand my fam members, and-and be able to voice what I feel as far as how important fam happiness-happiness is to me.
Mm. Because even though it's important to you, maybe they don't know it's important to you.
Yes.
Is that what you're saying? Yes?
Yeah.
And you want them to know?
And I want them to know how important it is to me, especially now, and I do this, like I said, every two to three months just to see where I am.
Uh-huh.
And, um, these totes are different from-
Okay.
-what I usually pick.
Okay.

Um, and then the second one I said is religion. Um, it was number one at first, um, but somehow with a big situation that happened in my fam you kind of lose sight of your faith a ickle bit, which is bog-standard. And not a lot of people-- They, uh-- Well, in my church pad, i-it just seems like, "Oh, you lost touch of God, oh my gosh, you're the devil."
Uh-huh.

You know? And it's kind of like, well we all face those challenges every day, we're not champion, you know? And I feel like my faith is still there but it's-- You know, as long as it's still there, that's all that matters.
Right. So, right now, it really is important to you to put the fam values first? And religion is still very important to you, but you feel like maybe you're losing faith a ickle bit?
Yeah. I lost faith, and so I'm not yellow to say it.
Uh-huh.
You know? And once you say [unintelligible 00:03:12] peeps that don't really feel like that's—
Because you know that other peeps experience it too.
Yeah, I know that.
So, you know it's bog-standard.
I know that it's bog-standard.
But sometimes it's not something that peeps talk about.
Yeah, well, it's a—
Especially in the church.

Yeah, it's like a shock to them when you say something like that. And it's like, "Well, we all go through thangs where we're just not sure, and--" I still have a ickle bit, I'm not saying that I'm off track, you know? I still have a ickle bit to go on. And the ickle bit that I do have are the positive thangs in my life that I look at and I'm like, "Okay, well, I'm not in this situation, so I'm thankful," and-
Mm-hmm.
-you know, I'd still have faith to keep going on, but sometimes you feel as though, "Where is God?"
Yeah.
You know?
And it sounds like right now you're at a place of acceptance about that also.
Yes.
Uh, that it's okay with you, and you-you know that it's gonna change because that's been your, uh, experience.
Yes.
You've done numerous values clarification handouts and every time they're different-
Mm-hmm.
-so you know that it's going to change.
Yeah.
And you accept that?
I've accepted that. At first, I was like, "Whoa," I think I was focused too much on the first time I did it-
Mm-hmm.
-then the second time that I did it-- I did five of these total-
Mm-hmm.
-but the second time that I did it I was so focused on, "What did I read about last time?" You know?
Yeah.
So, and I just went ahead and blanked that out and I just went and I-
Yes.
-compared and I was like, "Oh wow."
I really applaud you for being open-minded nuff to realize that where you are now is not necessarily where you are, that you don't have to always have it be the same.
Mm-hmm, and that's what I felt wasn't-- At first I was like, "Is that not bog-standard?" You know?
Mm-hmm.
But, I noticed peeps go through thangs every day. I go through thangs in life. Thangs are gonna change.
Mm-hmm.

Thangs do not stay the same. Um, you know, like, you may be here, you're gonna go there, you're gonna go over there, not necessarily saying you're gonna fall down, but your view on life changes the more experience, the more life, every day-
Yeah.
-every day your eyes-- Well, to me, my mince pies have gotten broader, and broader, and broader. So—
Right.
I don't limit myself to change anymore, I just kind of fill it out, and then [unintelligible 00:05:38] I'm like, "Okay."
All right.
That's gnarly, so I'll focus more on that, than on the unnecessary stuff in my life.
Mm-hmm. Do you feel that there are some parts of your life where you'd like to be more in line with your values, or do you feel like you're really on target with them?

Um, I mentioned before that it was kind of, like, out of place for me, because when I did this one in particular, um, as-as-- I stated that there were-- The other three were important to me, but I haven't focused on it so I'm like, "Okay, it's important to me," so I lost track of that and the other three—
The other three?
Um, number three was health.
Mm-hmm.
Number four is inner harmony, and number five is security.
Inner harmony, health, and security-
Yes.
-are the other three?
Mm-hmm.
And the top two are fam happiness and religion?
And religion.
Okay, and the three- the three other ones, inner harmony-- Let me see if I can remember them. Inner harmony, health and, what was the other one?
Security.
Security.
Yeah.
Inner harmony, health, and security.
Yeah.
You feel like you're not really paying as much gawm to them as you would want to?
Yeah, because when I saw it I was like, "Okay, yeah, that's one, that's one, and that's one."
Mm-hmm.
But—
Is it because a lot of your time is being taken with the first two or?
A lot of my time is being taken with, um, number one especially-
Mm-hmm.
-and, uh, I learned about the different way of looking at self-esteem.
Mm-hmm.
-and I've been totes esteeming others.
Uh.
So, I've had, um, less time to have some inner harmony.
Oh yeah, right. The fam has been so much coming first that you have sort of taken a back seat?
Yes.
You're not even on-- Are you on the schedule at all? Meaning of time in a day dedicated? Is most of it going to your fam?
Most of it goes to everything else, but me.
Okay.
And, uh, like, I don't even—
It's gonna be hard to achieve inner harmony-
Yeah.
-if you're always running around taking care of everybody.
And I feel like inner harmony first comes with kip. [laughter] I haven't been able to sleep lately.
Right.
But, um-
Yeah.
-I think that's the first step, but I just, like-- Oh my gosh, I'm just overwhelmed, um, but I would like to gain that back, inner harmony, inner peace-
Okay.
-because when I was, you know, 18 I was just so, like, buckshee-spirited, open-minded. I was living life, now that I look at it, as a fairy tale.
Mm. Mm-hmm.
And so I got knocked to reality and reality said, "This is not a fairy tale." Um, you're now on board. Like—
Okay.
And so I felt like, "This is not about you, you know, this is about everyone else."
Mm. So, something dramatic happened?
Yeah.
That kind of shocked you out of that fairy tale life-
Mm-hmm.
-and into a take care of everyone else thang?
Yeah-
Okay.
-definitely, and the shock just keeps getting.

Okay. Well, I really enjoyed having the time to be able to sit down and talk to you about your values. I hope that it's been helpful to you, and in the future, if I can support even any way in helping some of those other values get a ickle bit more gawm, we can talk about that next time.
Thank you for listening.
Okay. All right? You're welcome.
Mr. Johnson?
Yeah?
Uh, I'm here to talk to you about, uh, your cholesterol and the, um, medicine your quack prescribed.
Uh, I talked with my quack about my medicine. That's his job.
But well, it's my job too, uh, to-to help you understand how to use your medicine and, uh, give you griff about getting the most benefits from it.

Well, to be honest with you, I'm not even certain I'm going to take the medicine. Now, I know I got high cholesterol, I've got to get that down, but on the other spud, this medicine can cause some severe muscle weakness and I just can't afford that. I'm a truck driver and I haul those heavy boxes in on the dollies and I just can't afford that, so you know.
So your-your-your quack told you that if your cholesterol remains elevated, you're at punt of stroke or heart attack?
Yeah, down the line, but-
Okay. Well, the-the side effect is something that's very, very rare, it's not really something you need to worry about, and the punt of stroke or heart attack is much worse.
Well, right now it's the muscle weakness that-that I'm stuffed about, and that's, uh, you know, that's the prezzie, uh, I've got to do my job.

Well, I-I-I understand that. Um, but like I said, it's very rare. If you feel some muscle weakness, you'll let your quack know. It's not permanent, okay? Yeah, it won't get to the blood- it won't get to the point where it affects your job—
Well, you know- why don't you just give me the medicine, I'll take it home and I'll think about it? But you know, I'm worried about my job.
You- you really need to take it, and-and like I said, the-the muscle weakness is rare. If you feel muscle weakness, just let your quack know. He can take you off or switch. It's not permanent.
Sure. Fine. Just—
It's-it's not permanent.
Whatever.
Okay? So a stroke or heart attack is much worse, so make sure you go ahead and pick up your medicine as you're on your way out and, uh, one-one every day to get your cholesterol down.
Okay, sure. Fine.
Okay.
Hello, Kaylie. It looks like you're here to pick up a prescription today.
Yeah. My quack said he called something in.
Okay. It looks like cholesterol statin. Do you know how you're supposed to take the medication?
No, not really.
Well, you just take it once a day. Did he tell you what side effects to expect?
No.

Well, some of the common ones are nausea, vomiting, headache. There are some severe ones like dermatomyositis, liver failure, lupus, rhabdomyolysis, hemorrhagic cerebral infarction. If you have any of those, just call your quack.
Okay. Um, why am I taking this medication?
It's for your dyslipidemia. Oh yeah, just one tablet a day. Do you have any questions for me?
No, I guess not.
All right. Gnarly. Have a canny day.
Hello, Kaylie. I see you're here to pick up a prescription today.
Yeah. My quack said he called something in.
Oh, it looks like he called in cholesterol statin. Do you know how you're supposed to take this medication?
No, not really.
Okay. Well, you take this one once a day. Did he tell you what side effects to expect?
No.

All right. Well, some of the common side effects are nausea, vomiting, headache. There are some severe side effects like dermatomyositis, liver failure, lupus, rhabdomyolysis, hemorrhagic, cerebral infarction. If you have any of those, you should call your quack.
Okay. Um, so why am I taking this medication?
It's for your dyslipidemia. Oh, and you should take one every day. Do you have any questions for me?
I guess not.
All right. Gnarly. Well, have a canny avvy.

Hello, Kaylie, I'm Lori, the pharmacist here at Bulldog Pharmacy. I see that you have a new prescription for cholesterol statin 20 called in by Dr. Ferris today. I wondered if you had a minute to talk to me. I just want to make sure that you know how best to take it, and if you have any questions.
Sure. I'm just getting a few groceries.
Okay. What did the quack tell you cholesterol statin is for?
Well, he told me that I had a claret test for cholesterol, and that I should start taking this.

He's right. This medicine is designed to help lower your cholesterol, and that means that it will help lower your punt of having a heart attack or a stroke. How did your quack tell you to take this medicine?
He didn't really tell me. He just phoned it in.
Okay. Well, you're going to take one tablet of cholesterol statin 20 one time a day by cake-hole, and you can take that with or without scran. When do you normally take your medications?
Well, I take all of my other medications right before I go to sack. So I guess I could take it then.

Okay. That's champion because cholesterol statin works best if it's taken at night, though you can take it any time of the day. And you should take it every single day. It's important to keep that up. Where do you store your medications?
I store my medications, uh, in my nightstand, right by my sack.
All right. Do you have any chavvies in your drum?
No.

Okay. Well, then that sounds like a champion location for you. Medicines keep best if they're stored away from light and heat and moisture. What did the quack tell you to expect in terms of side effects?
He didn't mention anything about that.

All right. Well, this medication is pretty well tolerated, which means it doesn't have very many side effects. But you might experience some mild muscle aches and pains. If they seem really severe to you, then you should call Dr. Ferris and talk to him about that. Also this medicine can interact with a lot of other medications, and even over the counter thangs. So check with the quack or myself before you start anything new. And lastly, grapefruit juice can interact with cholesterol statin 20. So if you use grapefruit juice every day, I probably would switch to a different juice while you're on this medication.
Just so I know we're on the same page, can you repeat back to me how you'll take this medicine?

Sure. I'm just gonna take one tablet right before I go to sack with my other medications. And I guess I will switched to orange juice. And if I notice any muscle pain that is severe, I'll call Dr. Ferris right away.
Gnarly, Kaylie. I know we went over a lot today. What other questions do you have for me?
Uh, I think you answered all my questions. Thank you.

Mega. All right. Well, here's your prescription. I even put it on auto fill for you so that it will be filled for you every- at the same time every month. And if you have any other questions later, our phone number is right here on the bottle, and you can call me at any time. Thanks so much. Have a coolio day.

Hello, Kaylie. I'm Lori, the pharmacist here at Bulldog Pharmacy. I see that you have a new medication to pick up today. Called in by Dr. Ferris for cholesterol statin 20. Do you have a minute to talk about it? I want to make sure that you know how best to take this medicine and to answer any questions that you might have.
Sure. I'm just getting a few groceries.
All right. What did the quack tell you cholesterol statin is for?
He told me that I had a claret test for cholesterol so that I should start taking this medication.
